pageData.text: Effective land-use planning is critical in the development of the landscape to best suit our needs. Needs of an expanding population include agriculture, industry, commerce, recreation, and living spaces. All these purposes have various needs from the environment, which comes down to the soils and structure of the location. Some uses are appropriate for some soils but not for others. In addition, some soils may support multiple uses, and knowing soil properties helps us identify optimal uses and balance the needs of local communities with the ability of soils to support those needs. A <button class='glossary-text'>soil survey</button> is the most comprehensive way to evaluate the properties of a landscape and thus evaluate the most suitable use. In this investigation, you will perform a virtual soil survey and make recommendations for a land-use plan.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText: Activity 1: Performing a Virtual Soil Survey - 60 minutes
pageData.desc: Activity 1: Performing a Virtual Soil Survey - 60 minutes

text: Describe the basic components of a <button class='glossary-text'>soil survey</button>.
Demonstrate the ability to use online resources to analyze soil and environmental characteristics.
Explain the details of soil and environmental characteristics and possible <button class='glossary-text'>land use</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols
pageData.altText: video link symbol, camera symbol, stopwatch symbol

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Determining whether the soil can support the weight of a structure is one of the most important concerns for architects and structural engineers. They need to get detailed soil profiles to make sure the soil will not deform under the weight of the building; and based on the soil properties, they build foundations that take into account the type and consistency of the area. When these factors are not considered, the consequences can be dramatic. One of the most famous examples of this is the Leaning Tower of Pisa in Italy. The tower’s construction was completed in 1370, but the tower began to lean almost as soon as construction began 200 years earlier. While blame has gone back and forth over the centuries, whether it was the architect’s fault or the fault of the soil, most modern-day analysts believe the soil profile played a significant role in the tower’s tilt. The soil beneath the tower has layers of incompressible clay with a layer of sandy silt on top that was thicker on one side than the other. The tower’s foundation was too small and shallow to counteract this difference and the tower began to lean. Recent efforts have been made to stabilize the tower from tilting any further while still preserving the characteristic lean of this world-famous landmark.

1Panwar, R. (2020, September 28). Leaning Tower of Pisa: An Architectural Marvel or Engineering Failure? The Constructor.
https://theconstructor.org/case-study/leaning-tower-of-pisa-tilt/63377/

<button class='glossary-text'>Land use</button> is the term used to describe human interaction with the land and includes economic and cultural activities. With a growing population, determination of land use is important. Some land is suitable for multiple uses; thus choices must be made based on climate and local needs. For example, the soil in a flat grassy valley has the structure to support building developments and roads for commerce but is also fertile for agriculture; the needs for food security may prioritize that land for agriculture. Areas also suitable for agriculture are river deltas, which are rich in minerals <button class='glossary-text'>deposited</button> from years of sedimentation. However, farming in these areas could damage the land’s ability to provide buffering from coastal storms. Given this important ecosystem service, should this land be preserved or tilled for agriculture? Decisions such as these are important to protect and utilize land most effectively. A properly conducted <button class='glossary-text'>soil survey</button> informs a planner on many important factors needed to make use decisions, including a general description of the survey area, history, human activity, water drainage and physiography, geology, climate, and soil structure.

pageData.subTitle: General Nature of the Survey Area
pageData.text: Soil surveys pertain to a specific area. The area surveyed should be described very clearly so it can be used by current and future developers. The survey location must include the area with reference within a state, distance, and direction from major cities or towns. Distance and direction from any large bodies of water and rivers/streams are all useful. Other information includes acreage of the land surveyed, elevation, and references to any geographical landmarks.

pageData.subTitle: History
pageData.text: A knowledge of the history of an area of land is important for several reasons. Humans have been part of the landscape for thousands of years, and native cultural sites need to be respected. Informative details include location of known camps, travel routes, and any seasonal activity/migration routes (see Figure 1). To this point, ancient people have lived and left artifacts important to their people and to all human society.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Remains of Native American homes built in the side of a mountain
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Remains of Native American homes built in the side of a mountain

pageData.text: In the US and Canada, understanding the discovery and settlement by early Europeans is an important part of an area’s history. Governance may have changed over time from a colony, inclusion into statehood, and even federal governance. Also, description of any nearby cities, how they were built, why the location of the city was chosen, and historic shifts in population are included. Reasons for a location could be as simple as the location was near a railroad, port, or highway intersection. Other important inclusions are local industry that may support the community, especially those that could inform on the landscape, such as agriculture, timber industry, or even tourism.

pageData.subTitle: Transportation Facilities
pageData.text: A brief description of the regional infrastructure for transportation can differ greatly, depending on the local population intensity. Important infrastructure to include are the presence of county, state, and federal highways; bridges over waterways; railroads; airlines; and the presence of public transportation.

pageData.subTitle: Physiography
pageData.text: The soils of a region were formed by a variety of processes, including erosion, deposition by glaciers or streams, or plate tectonics in the case of <button class='glossary-text'>bedrock</button>. These processes, along with climate, shaped the landscape and are described by their common physical geography. Current descriptions of the physical geography exist at large scales (see Figure 2) and local (see Figure 3), both of which can inform on the development and composition of soils.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Color-coded US map labeled from 1 to 25 to illustrate the country’s physical geography
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Color-coded US map labeled from 1 to 25 to illustrate the country’s physical geography

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Map illustrating important farmland in Oklahoma
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Map illustrating important farmland in Oklahoma

pageData.subTitle: Sediment Deposition by Water, Wind, and Ice
pageData.text: Due to their unconsolidated (loose) nature, sediments can develop into soils more quickly than solid <button class='glossary-text'>bedrock</button>. Describing water flow, drainage, and the landscapes from which they travel can inform how sediments came to be <button class='glossary-text'>deposited</button> in a location. The origin of a river in a specific mountain range, the type of rock material it cuts through along with the slope, and the valley it runs through and depositing sediment material along the way are valuable in determining the parent material of a soil. In regions formerly covered in glaciers, such as much of the Midwestern US, glacier-deposited sediments, called glacial till, are also common. Glacial till contains a diverse mixture of rocks reflecting the rocks that the glacier eroded before it melted. Glaciers also grind up sediment into a fine sediment, and some of these particles can be picked up by the wind. Such wind-deposited silt particles (0.002–0.05 mm in diameter) are called loess. Wind can also move sand particles (0.05–2 mm in diameter) previously deposited by rivers and the ocean, creating sand dunes from which soil may eventually form. Geology can be thought of how major historic events shape the rocks and soils around us. By examining the geologic timeline, we see how both the evolution of life over millions of years and <button class='glossary-text'>geographical events</button> shape the composition and structure of our landforms (see Figure 4).

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Potential location for a soil survey. Soil types are distinguished on the map by yellow lines. Each has its own mapping unit label (examples, Ys and Sp).
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Potential location for a soil survey. Soil types are distinguished on the map by yellow lines. Each has its own mapping unit label (examples, Ys and Sp).

pageData.text: Bare rock and soils are the result of bedrock formation millions of years ago and their and deposition over time. The parent material for soils provides the soil its mineral and physical characteristics. Thus, cataloging rock formation age, time of any large sediment deposit events, and the mineral composition are extremely informative.

pageData.subTitle: Climate
pageData.text: Describing the climate of a region is extremely informative in land-use planning. It can provide details not only about potential uses but, notably, uses that developers should be wary of. Seasonal patterns and presence of rainfall are important for agriculture decisions but also human infrastructure in the case of flooding potential. Additionally, climate plays a critical role in soil formation and thus its classification. This is largely due to two main factors: temperature and water.

Water, as both a chemical and physical <button class='glossary-text'>weathering</button> agent, is critical to soil formation. Both a greater volume of precipitation and greater intensity of rainfall accelerate weathering and therefore hasten overall soil development. Nearby streams may also contribute to soil development by depositing fresh sediment or halt development altogether by eroding soil away before it can fully form. Additional physical weathering can occur due to the physical property of water where it expands upon freezing, which can break apart rocks during the winter, and in cases where soils absorb water, causing them to expand. In addition, the presence of water is necessary for many chemical reactions; thus, in the presence of water, chemical weathering occurs. Other chemical weathering reactions include acid-base reactions facilitated by organisms. Wet climates are particularly good at supporting tree growth, and these trees-especially conifersexude copious acids from their roots that react with and weather soil minerals. Acids may also originate from human-caused acid rain, occurring downwind from fossil fuel combustion.

Temperature also plays a critical role in soil formation, and its role is interrelated with the presence of water in many cases. One main role of temperature is that with higher temperature, chemical reactions are sped up; conversely, in regions that experience expanded periods of freezing, reactions are dramatically slowed. In regions that experience seasonal fluctuations, expanding and contracting of the soils persist throughout the year. Additionally, temperature patterns can influence the presence of water, which is important not only for the above-mentioned reasons but also impacts the presence and productivity of plant life. Plants not only impact soils through weathering via their roots, mineral usage, and inputs in organic matter, but they also support local biota, which have their own inputs.

pageData.question: Which of these is a possible result of large temperature swings on soil formation?

options.text: Water in rocks and soil can freeze, causing rocks to break and soil to expand.
Increased temperature will slow down chemical reactions that result in soil formation.
Decreased temperature will increase chemical reactions that result in soil formation.
Increased temperature will evaporate water, which is favorable for conifers and soil formation.
Local biota cannot be supported in very cold environments, thus minimizing soil formation.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Physical weathering and soil formation can occur due to the physical property of water where it expands upon freezing, which can break apart rocks during the winter, and in cases where soils absorb water, causing them to expand.

pageData.question: Which of these is a possible result of rainfall on soil development?

options.text: An increase in rainfall will swell streams and erode sediment and deposit it elsewhere.
A decrease in rainfall will halt soil formation.
An increase in rainfall will constantly wash away sediment so it cannot support organic matter.
A decrease in rainfall will create dry conditions that will speed up soil formation.
An increase in rainfall will flood a region and prevent plants from taking root.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Water, as both a chemical and physical weathering agent, is critical to soil formation. Both a greater volume of precipitation and greater intensity of rainfall accelerate weathering and therefore hasten overall soil development. Nearby streams may also contribute to soil development by depositing fresh sediment or halt development altogether by eroding soil away before it can fully form.

pageData.subTitle: Soils
pageData.text:
Soil descriptions comprise the bulk of a and are founded upon soil taxonomy, which classifies soils according to their key characteristics. Soils are classified in a hierarchical system including six levels: Order, Suborder, Great Group, Subgroup, Family, and Series. There are 12 in the taxonomic system that are largely defined by the presence or absence of diagnostic horizons and other properties that reflect the soils’ formation conditions.
  • Moderately leached soils with relatively high fertility. They are commonly formed under forests and have a subsurface horizon in which clays have accumulated. They are often found in temperate humid and subhumid regions.
  • Formed in volcanic ash and are largely composed of glass and weathered minerals. These soils have unique chemical and physical properties, including high water-holding capacity and the ability to fix high quantities of phosphorus.
  • Calcium carbonate-containing soils of arid regions with some subsurface horizon development. They are dry most of the year with limited leaching. Subsurface accumulates clays, calcium carbonate, silica, salts, and gypsum.
  • Soils of recent origin that developed from unconsolidated parent material. They usually consist of only an A horizon.
  • Soils of very cold climates that contain permafrost within 2 meters of depth.
  • Composed of at least 20% organic matter that is more than 40 centimeters thick. These are often found near wetlands with limited drainage.
  • Soils of recent origin but with some horizon development. They are often found on steep mountain slopes.

• Characterized by a thick, dark surface horizon that resulted from long-term addition of organic material. They are very fertile soils of grassland ecosystems.
  • Highly weathered soils that are rich in iron and aluminum oxides. They are low in other minerals due to the nature of heavy and are found in intertropical regions. Consequently, these soils have very low nutrient levels and very low fertility.
  • Acidic soils that occur under coniferous forests in cool and moist climates. They have a subsurface accumulation of humus with a light-colored E horizon above a reddish-brown spodic horizon.
  • Strongly leached and acidic forest soils in humid temperate and tropical areas. They are of relatively low fertility due to intense weathering and leaching of minerals.
  • Clay-rich soils that expand or contract with the presence of water.
    Well-developed horizons are not present, and these soils are characterized by cracking when dry.

Much finer characteristics of soils are defined in the other taxonomic groups and are finally defined in soil surveys at the series classification level. There are over 20,000 soil series descriptions in the USDA-NRCS catalog. To obtain this level of classification, many tests are conducted on the physical and chemical properties of the soil.

In this investigation, you will select a location of interest and determine what <button class='glossary-text'>land uses</button> the soil could support. To determine possible land uses for your location, you will remotely identify the soils present at the series level and describe their characteristics.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. In activity 1, you will open the SoilWeb platform and choose a region. Then,m you will take a screenshot of your region and describe it. Next, you will record the soil classification, soil series and soil characteristics. You will do this for 3 regions. Finally, you will determine the best land use for each region based on its soil type.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Why should the history of an area be included in a soil survey?

options.text: Native cultural sites need to be respected.
The area’s history will reveal if major meteorological events have occurred.
The area’s history informs us how to provide food security.
The area’s history describes the direction of any large bodies of water and rivers.
A soil survey may have already been done in this area.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a major way in which temperature influences soil formation?

options.text: It speeds up or slows down chemical reactions.
It shapes the rocks and soils.
It has no effect on soil formation.

assestmentData.question: The parent material of a soil provides which of the following to the soil?
Which soil order includes soils that are moderately leached soils and commonly formed under forests?
Which soil is largely composed of glass and weathered minerals?
Which soil would you find under coniferous forests?
Approximately how many different soil series descriptions are there?
What factors are the most important to soil formation and classification?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

In Activity 1, you will choose three different regions using the SoilWeb online soil browser and examine the soil classification and characteristics of each region. You will then make recommendations for <button class='glossary-text'>land use</button> in each region based on the soil type.
Open the SoilWeb online soil browser from the California Soil Resource Lab. Click on “SoilWeb”.
Note: At the bottom of the SoilWeb Apps page, there are also apps available for Android or iPhone and a text-only version. The apps will provide data on your location.

Using the map browser and zoom function in the menu, locate a region of your choice in the United States that contains a diversity of habitats and thus, a diversity of soil types. You may need to zoom out until you find the location you are interested in. When you zoom in, make sure your focus location is in the middle of your screen. Soil types are distinguished on the map by yellow lines and yellow abbreviations.
Take a screenshot of your survey area (see example, <button class='resource-text'>Figure 4</button>). Upload your image to the Lab Notebook.

Make a general description of the survey area. Take care not to select an area too large (in which a great diversity of landscapes exists) and not too small (in which only one soil type is present). The general description should include proximity to cities/towns, water resources, human infrastructure, and geographical information.
To select the soils within a region, click anywhere within a region to access the soil map units, which will appear in the top left of your screen.

In Data Table 1, record the soil classification and abbreviation, the four most abundant soils present (series level), and the percent abundance and geomorphic position of each. This information can be found in the blue and gray box at the top left of the screen.

In the blue and gray box at the top left of the screen, click on the series name of the most prevalent soil type. Click on “Description” at the top right of the tab to gain access to specific information about the soil series. Record the series in
Data Table 2.

In Data Table 2, record the taxonomic class, briefly describe the soil characteristics, location, geographic setting, drainage and permeability, and usage. Depending on the location you have chosen, you may need to scroll down to find the information required for Data Table 2.
Note: For additional information on a soil series, the Soil Data Explorer from the California Soil Resource Lab is also useful.
Repeat Steps 5–8 for two additional nearby regions that have a different soil classification (determined by the abbreviation).
Summarize your findings and recommendations in the “Data Summary”.

data.title: Alfisols
data.content: The soil order comprised of leached basic or slightly acidic soils with a clay-enriched B horizon

data.title: Andisols
data.content: The soil order comprised of black or dark brown soil formed from volcanic material with an A horizon rich in organic material

data.title: Aridisols
data.content: The soil order comprissed of typically saline or alkaline soils with very little organic matter; it is characteristic of arid regions

data.title: Bedrock
data.content: Solid rock underlying loose deposits, such as soil or alluvium

data.title: Entisols
data.content: The soil order comprised of mineral soils that have not yet differentiated into distinct horizons

data.title: Gelisols
data.content: The soil order comprised of soils of very cold climates that contain permafrost within 2 meters of depth

data.title: Geographical event
data.content: A major event that occurred geographically in history, such as an earthquake, glacial flow, mass extinction, etc.

data.title: Histosols
data.content: The soil order comprised of peaty soils with a deep surface layer of purely organic material

data.title: Inceptisols
data.content: The soil order comprised of freely draining soils in which the formation of distinct horizons is not far advanced, such as brown Earth

data.title: Land use
data.content: Human interaction with the land to include economic and cultural activities

data.title: Mollisols
data.content: The soil order comprised of temperate grassland soils with a dark humus-rich surface layer containing high concentrations of calcium and magnesium

data.title: Oxisols
data.content: The soil order comprised of stable, highly weathered, tropical mineral soils with highly oxidized subsurface horizons

data.title: Soil order
data.content: The broadest taxonomic level of soil classification in a system based on measurable and observable soil properties

data.title: Soil survey
data.content: A systematic study of the soil of an area including classification and mapping of the properties, crop adaptations, and distribution of various soil types

data.title: Spodosols
data.content: The soil order comprised of acidic soils that occur under coniferous forests in cool and moist climates

data.title: Ultisols
data.content: the soil order comprised of strongly leached and acidic forest soils in humid temperate and tropical areas

data.title: Vertisols
data.content: the soil order comprised of clay-rich soils with little organic matter in regions having distinct wet and dry seasons

data.title: Weathering
data.content: The breaking down or dissolving of rocks and minerals on Earth's surface
